Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2014 09:58AM JillThut wrote: Funny on the cannabis thing.  My kids like to promote that idea every chance they get...especially one in particular.  At first diagnosis over four years ago my older son had brought me a joint and stuck it in a drawer..  Finally that Thanksgiving I was so sick from chemo nausea I got the thing out of the drawer and went into my daughter's room and asked her how to smoke it.  What my kids don't get is that I've never smoked..period...not that and not even cigarettes.  So she's trying to teach me how to inhale and when I finally did I felt like I'd swallowed an ashtray.  Luckily I had brought a bucket in with me so I immediately started vomiting in it.  Even the smell of it nauseates me...in fact even the thought of the smell nauseates me. Last year they brought me a candy...size of a jolly rancher...ate the whole thing.  It didn't help either..not only that..it did give me some unwanted side effects...weird sensations...anxiety.  Took 1 mil of Ativan to counteract it and fell asleep. At one point the APRN agreed to prescribe Marinol but all the local pharmacies were out of it. (One told me that the drug companies will make it unavailable for a time and then bring it back on at a higher price) Ultimately when my onc returned from vacation she said she would not prescribe it.  I would fight for it if I had faith it would work but I don't. I did just buy some ginger spice drops and am going to go back for the crystallized ginger at pearlady's suggestion on another thread.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2014 10:15AM JillThut wrote: I've been prescribed Ativan for nausea but it's never worked for me.  I always have some on hand for MRI anxiety.  Recently when I take it while nauseated it will either put me over the edge and make me throw up or if I'm lucky it will knock me out first and I'll fall asleep. My sister brought me some crystallized ginger yesterday.  They definitely seem to have more ginger than the gum drop ones I originally bought.  And if the nausea is light they will quell it fir a bit but only a very short time.  The zofran kind of works the same way..it last about 20 minutes to an hour..tops. Maybe I will revisit the marinol idea with my onc when I see her next week. Fluffernutter, I think probably, like me, you are sitting there appreciating all the advice, but probably have tried most of the suggestions.  Maybe there's a couple you haven't, like acupuncture (sent to me in a private message).  That's one I might consider but would need to feel confident about it working since it would be costly. As an aside...I actually had a pretty good day yesterday.  First one in months!  I really was glad to have it but by the time I went to bed I was very nauseated..and even resentful.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 03:06PM JillThut wrote: Not sure what you mean by palliative when it comes to chemo. Any of the chemos your oncologist prescribes would be with the purpose of keeping your mets at bay or possibly even shrinking some. Gemcitabine is just another option. I was just on it for four months and in my case I was on that one specifically because my onc knew I wanted a hair sparing option. It did not work for me though., but I did find it easy to tolerate except that it lowered my white cell counts. We can all relate to the shakiness of knowing our options are limited. Guess as long as we're alive we can hope that other options come along. I have not...as of yet ...had the experience of feeling that my oncologist has given up on me...quite the contrary..I am pleased that she seems to be always thinking ahead as far as the next option. I dread the day that happens. Hope you have many options remaining.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2012 05:58AM - edited Apr 7, 2012 06:12AM by JillThut "Additionally, ASCO suggests that oncologists avoid the use of advanced imaging technologies to assess early-stage breast or prostate cancers that are unlikely to spread, forgo the use of advanced imaging or blood tests for biomarkers" In my personal case.... after an initial stage IIB diagnosis and a lumpectomy and radiation...I saw the oncology team every three months for two years..all just checking the breasts manually. Ne'er a scan and a yr and a half without even a tumor marker test. Took my GP to find extensive spread to the liver after I finally came down with symptoms two yrs later. In retrospect the onc says the mets were probably there all along and admits that 'theoretically being a little cancer vs a lot of cancer' I might have had a better prognosis if we had known about it earlier.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2012 06:45AM JillThut wrote: All true, Lago. In fact having seen my mother go through it in an era when further scans were automatic i did ask immediately after my diagnosis if that would be the next step for me. The reply was that "We don't do that anymore since sometimes we see things that aren't cancer and end up alarming people unnecessarily". I agreed with that since my mother's scan showed a shadow on her liver that ended up being nothing. He also added that if i had metastatic disease I would have symptoms...not true in my case. Still there seems to be something wrong with being "monitored aggressively" every three months by cancer specialists and it takes my GP to send me for an ultrasound of the liver after having flu like symptoms to discover mets. Yes it sucks...but i understand fully the "unpredictability" in medicine and life in general and i would prefer to think that scanning wouldn't have made a difference in my case anyway (although it likely would have). Just throwing it out there for one perspective on the scanning issue.

Posts.Content: May 19, 2013 06:17AM JillThut wrote: I've never had affinitor but have had plenty of nausea! Can't stand it and since the antinauseas don't even touch it when it's severe I figured I had to just suck it up. However when I reported it to the APRN she was very adamant about the fact that I shouldn't have to suffer and tried a regimen with me that actually worked to a point. ...didn't take it away completely but made it a lot more tolerable. What I was on at that time was carboplatin and taxotere. The taxotere requires steroids as a premed so her solution was to continue the steroids for a week after treatment. (not sure if u can do that one if you're not already getting oral steroids..but maybe). She also said to take the zofran every 8 hours whether I felt nauseated or not. Ativan at bedtime if needed. And she suggested going back into the center for intravenous fluids and antinauseas in the IV since they are more effective that way. I have to say I had my doubts but I followed to the t exactly what she suggested and that round was much more tolerable. Hope you find a solution or can move to something more tolerable!

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2013 09:46AM JillThut wrote: Here's my 2 cents: First of all I don't know what predicts how long a person has to live when it comes to liver mets. I also have multiple..more than ten..the largest of which is 7.5 cm. One of our dear sisters on here had mets in the same places as I did..bones and liver. I also have brain mets (albeit it few, small, and so far contained with gamma knife) but she did not. I know her liver mets were smaller than mine and yet she is already gone and I'm still here. My liver functions are still normal. I'm surprised that your oncologist would suggest throwing in the towel because doxil may not be effective since you've already had 2 chemos. I am currently on doxil which is my 8th chemo in four years. Taxol, Xeloda, Navelbine, Gemzar, Carboplatin/Taxotere, Perjeta/Taxotere, Kadcyla, and now Doxil. I am awaiting my second doxil infusion as we speak. Kind of hard to judge side effects based on only one treatment but definitely not a chemo hell. Carbo/Tax was chemo hell for me. So far this is a piece of cake. Personally I would try it. If the side effects are mild and you can still change your mind at any point, what's the harm?

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 06:52AM JillThut wrote: If you mean if the "cure" of trying to control the symptoms got me to a point of being functional enough to work...I'd have to say absolutely not. Not sure how long you've been doing this but I'm past three years with extensive liver mets and really feel the game is getting close to over. I had a good normal functioning for three years though so not complaining but I've been barely functional for the past few months. If you can do it financially, moving to part time might be a good idea...not too many people die wishing they had spent more time at work. But i wouldn't judge it from how you're feeling right now 'cause my guess is right now you're not up for working at all. If you're going to continue this regimen you might have to consider short term disability for a while if it's an option and play it by ear. Maybe you'll switch to a different treatment eventually and feel perfectly fine again...and perhaps will appreciate a part time schedule anyway at that point.

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2013 05:21PM JillThut wrote: Wish I had some encouraging words.  I found Carboplatin extremely intolerable and they haven't even added that for you yet.  I did three rounds of it and I have to say that the advice to try to control the side effects is good because by the third round the PA had suggested intravenous IV fluids, a week of steroids..round the clock zofran, ativan...and I have to say it was more tolerable.  Kicked it to the curb anyway in favor of perjeta even though the carbo actually gave me the first regression in over a year.  But at what point is it really helping if you have no quality of life.  With the carbo my onc convinced me to stay the third round so she could scan and see the results. Sorry you're suffering so much.  It really stinks.  But see if you can get some other suggestions from your medical people to lessen the side effects..and if not you may have to make a decision.  Also there is always and outside chance you may become more tolerant of it if you hang on.  Most chemos I've  been on have made me sick at first dose.
Posts.Title: How long do you wait to see if chemo is tolerable? SAMayoFL JillThut

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 05:55AM JillThut wrote: I was getting taxotere along with the carboplatin and it requires steroids the day before, day of and day after. So the PA wrote out a schedule for me to continue the steroids for a week...tapering off toward the end of the week. She also said to take the oral zofran every 8 hours needed or not and take Ativan at night for nausea if needed. I did go in once two days after the infusion for intravenous fluids and got intravenous Ativan but I honestly am not sure that that did anything...so the rest was all oral. I followed to the letter everything she said to do without having any faith it would make a difference but it did! It still wasn't a walk in the park but more tolerable. Nausea is the worst!

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2012 04:32PM JillThut wrote: All good questions. Too bad you couldn't get definitive answers from the LTD company ahead of time but probably won't happen. I have SSDI and LTD since I left work 7/2010. I'm 54. The LTD is minimal ..100 dollars per month. But I will say they harass me every six months for it. Long forms to complete about daily activities and such. They want every pay stub from every job I've worked when I work and it's minimal. They keep me on the phone for at least 45 minutes and then send mounds of paperwork for me and onc....every six months! It seems they are trying very hard to find reasons not to pay. Maybe you could ask your onc how they would complete the paperwork for you, basically as far as how sick they would make you look despite being NED. They certainly could still make it work since treatment has side effects etc. Maybe you should talk to them about it. Hopefully some NEDsters will come along with their experiences.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2014 05:14PM JillThut wrote: You may remember a few weeks back I was sharing nausea stories with fluffier nutter.  I think she was relatively new to sharing on here.  Fluff..Amy ....even mentioned that she and I were on the same cycle since we coincidentally had both had one good day on the same day.  When we found the regimen in the hospital that worked for me....dekadron and zyprexa...I shared it in a PM with Amy. About a week later I received a pm response from Amy's daughter telling me she had passed.  It saddened me greatly..including giving me a lot of survivor's remorse. Aside from that it looks like I'm going mostly to palliative care.  My liver is too compromised at the moment to continue any chemo although that could change.  Bone and CAT scans today...MRI on 5/27.   I also have a consultation with palliative that day...which my three children will all attend.  So I switched focus to important stuff like the kids which Is why I haven't visited the boards much lately. Palliative care people are supposed to now monitor whatever I am taking for symptom management.  Problem is I'm out of most meds and no one seems to know who ininitially prescribed what ?!?!?!   Everything constipates me..been literally crawling around the house in pain..until my beloved four year grandson crawled onto the counter for me to fetch the last of the lactulose. After that it dawned on me I do have stronger stuff so announced to my family that to get out of pain I intend to launch a relationship with "Oxy...knocks your socks off Moron! Until I can get out if this terrible rectal pain!!!!" Nice to is you've been thinking of me..so there's the latest.
Posts.Title: JillThut april485 Mompsych

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 08:40AM JillThut wrote: When I complained of fatigue recently one of my favorite triage nurses returned the call and suggested I hydrate, buy some spinach, and "you may not like this one but you should exercise at least three times a week". I have been exercising every morning since I was in my twenties! Nothing big..sit ups and such...but really. I jokingly warned her not to treat me like a "newbie". She had never heard of Ritalin for this use and oddly enough neither had my onc so they referred me to the palliative care team at Yale. With some arm twisting I got them to meet me in the infusion room when I had to be there anyway. Very nice dr who agreed to accommodate me on my schedule. Prescribed 2.5 mil twice a day while telling me that it should be at least 5 to work. I didn't mind 'cause I want to start off slow anyway. Been on that dose nearly a week. So far it has made me a little jittery..has not helped the fatigue..and is keeping me awake at night. I have an Ativan prescription which I use mostly for MRI claustrophobia but occasionally I'll take half a mil at night if I feel sick and can't sleep. I called to get more of that before my trip cause I don't want to be without it. My onc prescribed only 20 because she doesn't like me taking it because it has to metabolize through my compromised liver. I know many of you take it regularly for anxiety but I never have cause I'm just not anxious generally speaking. But if I were, it looks like she wouldn't give it to me. I mean am I not at the point that it really doesn't matter? I think the palliative care people would be more willing. I love my onc and she is realistic but maybe coming more from a point of "healing" and not doing further harm where the palliative care people now it's more about symptom control?

When I failed on taxol I went to xeloda for a year which is how I ended up with hair...also navelbine and Gemzar don't cause hair loss.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2013 03:30PM JillThut wrote: When we're on a chemo that doesn't work for us at all we're usually on it for 3 months until we discover it was ineffective. So that's like being on nothing. So if you've been on nothing for two months, can you go another two...and then scan and then make a decision depending on whether there's progression then? That's only four months and if you progress in that time you may have progressed anyway on yet another ineffective terrible side effect chemo severely cutting into your QOL. Your body probably needs a break. And I wholeheartedly agree with Bestbird on the diet, supplements and whatever thing...which is odd coming from me because I most certainly do not practice it. Whatever you decide.. Enjoy feeling well and rock out to some more tunes!

Posts.Content: JillThut wrote: just because it's your last chance and really doesnt mater anymore? My hospital room on the 14th floor has a huge window that looks out directly over the helipad. There was a man out there this morning shoveling snow off it and I got this silly idea that it might be fun to stand up in the window and flash him! I refrained, of course, mostly because I figured it would send him screaming and running in the other direction, possibly off the edge of the building and I couldn't bear the guilt. I've been here since last Thursday due to perjeta induced fever and severe sore throat. Came in with a dangerously low blood pressure and elevated heart rate. My long awaited perjeta diarrhea finally kicked in that morning so I spent the first few days in ICU tethered to the bed by a heart monitor, blood pressure monitor, and IV of course. Had a commode at the side of the bed which I used about every half hour. Dozed off in between commode visits since I had morphine for the throat pain. They wouldn't treat the diarrhea for several days either because they first wanted to rule out c-diff. Anyway...just thought I'd share...going home today and grateful to be back among the living even if only for a short while... bone, liver and brain mets Jill Dx 10/6/2009, Stage IV, mets Dx IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 07:42PM JillThut wrote: I dreaded the port too...I have very good accessible veins and did not want a port. My biggest reason was because I though knowing this foreign thing was in my body would prevent me fro staying in denial in between infusions...just knowing it was there! But had to have it put in due to navelbine. For me the procedure was a piece of cake...no pain...I was awake and oddly enough, had no problem listening to the team talk about the procedure while they were doing it. Versed is a wonderful drug! :). Definitely get the Emla cream...BEFORE they access it the first time. It needs to be put on at least an hour in advance to numb the area. Mine is a double port....something I was not expecting...but that's what the onc ordered without informing me...you might want to ask so there are no surprises. I'm still trying to find reasons to like it....and the fact that both your arms are free is definitely a plus! The infusion room can be hot cold, hot cold....so now I can actually easily take a sweater on and off! Glad Nancy weighed in on this...she is definitely the port queen! :)

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2012 04:40PM JillThut wrote: Have been on xeloda for almost a year. Tykerb and xeloda for the past two months. Bear in mind that everyone is different...and most of what i have to report is good. The xeloda initially knocked me for a loop..severe diarrhea and mild nausea...taking it two weeks on and a week off. Dr reduced the dose and changed the schedule...to a week on and a week off...much better! I was back to normal! She wanted to give me tykerb at that time but by the time they got an approval for it i wasn't tolerating the xeloda well so we stuck with xeloda and herceptin. I was also having excellent scans on xeloda. It was actually shrinking tumors where the taxol (17mo of it) was just keeping it at bay. Due to recent brain mets we switched the herceptin for tykerb a couple months ago...so far so good. Unfortunately xeloda and tykerb both have the same side effects..diarrhea and hand/foot syndrome. So taking them together can give you a double whammy. I was very apprehensive when we added the tykerb but so far so good. My fingers get cracked sometimes making it hurt to bend them...but not intolerable. I put bandaids on my thumbs where they bend. It keeps them moist and then they're fine. My feet get red and burn on the bottom sometimes..like walking on hot sand. Its really not all that bad so i hope im not making it sound bad. These symptoms come and go...it's not like they get red and stay red and get progressively worse..not at all....in fact I dance regularly...if it causes burning feet I just ice em when im done. Not into following rules...like avoiding heat and friction....if its going to interfere with my quality of life. Don't get discouraged if you don't tolerate it well in the beginning. Hated it with a passion initially...hated hearing that the taxol was no longer working..even was upset at the plug being pulled on my regular weekly infusion routine. But now I can almost sing its praises. Plus i got to grow hair after two years! Not necessarily a good thing since it's a lot less tame than the wig...but it's mine! Good luck with it...and don't despair. Ive heard lots of reports of good scans on it.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 08:09AM JillThut wrote: Having a terminal illness I was also concerned about my life ins for my kids thinking...gee..im leaving cause im dying...do I need to actually drop dead on the job in order for my beneficiaries to collect? Asked the ? Of HR. The response: "Well you might be able to continue it and pay on your own if the company accepts you.". Duh! Who is going to insure a terminally I'll person? Doubted her answer so researched it myself. She was 'dead' wrong! Not only could I keep the life insurance, but also am exempt from paying a premium due to the fact that I left work due to a 'disability' prior to retirement age. I'm 54. Not only that...but if your dr says you are expected to live less than x number of months (for my Anthem plan it was 12) you can take a percentage of the money before you go..anywhere from 50 - 100 percent depending on the plan. Anthem was 75 percent and I took it. It is also a tax free transaction by the way. And with the Anthem plan if you should miraculously recover you are not required to pay it back. The 25 percent remaining is still there for my beneficiaries without my having to pay for it
Posts.Title: disability Lauriesh JillThut

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 12:18AM JillThut wrote: Just be sure that the insurance you take an accelerated death benefit from doesn't have that clause that says you owe interest on what you took...my anthem policy at work didn't but my private policy does which is why i didn't take that one..although I may have to if I run out of employment options. I saw a thread on here a while back with people having that issue of being charged interest from an accelerated death benefit. Jcb51 regarding unemployment...used to be ...at least in CT that u have to be available for full time work in order to collect unemployment....that changed..I believe in 2006...now if u have a documented disability you can be seeking part time work and still collect unemployment and yes at the same time as SS disability...I have been doing just that until recently when the unemployment ran out :(. And I believe you can earn 1010 and not jeopardize you SS disability...as someone above pointed out...scuttlers I believe....she had pretty much all the rules spelled out accurately...and you can read it in the SS disability handbook or on the website.

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2012 01:37PM - edited Sep 5, 2012 01:43PM by JillThut So sorry for your loss, Sarika. "I know my mother gave me some beautiful moments to remember her by and I hope I get to those memories faster and forget about the recent events that led to her passing". I'm glad to hear you say that. I think you have certainly inherited some of your mother's strength and positive attitude. The above quote is something I have tried to explain to friends who seem stuck on the not so pleasant ending of the lives of their loved ones. I have also said it to my kids. If the last weeks or hours of life produce suffering try not to dwell on that. It pales compared to years and years of memories. If your mother suffered at the end, for her it was short lived. I'm sure she wouldn't want you to carry it forever. I lost my mother who was my best friend to metastatic breast cancer exactly two months prior to my mets diagnosis. I feel like our closeness somehow has made the loss easier to bear. I hope it will comfort you in the days to come as well.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 12:21PM - edited Jan 29, 2013 01:22PM by JillThut Many of us have lived with this same issue for the 24 months prior to being eligible or Medicare. I remained on COBRA at around 600 per month for just me..no spouse until Medicare eligibility this January. It was a struggle but necessary. In the beginning when my income just didn't support it I have to say the luck of a shed collapsing due to snow and other related house ins claims gave me some unexpected funds that I paid the insurance with as pathetic as that sounds. I also took advantage of assistance from the Healthwell foundation who helped me with premium payment assistance...1800 in total which was a godsend. There are other funds out there that might be able to help assist paying other things so you can pay your COBRA. I realize that I might be somewhat "luckier" than you I the sense that I did not have a second income via a spouse that might have made me ineligible for certain help. After going out on ss disability I was able to collect Unemployment while looking for part time work which was legitimate due to the disability. Also..having worked part time even a minimal number of hours made me eligible for medicaid for the working disabled which has income/ asset limits that are much higher than the low income eligibility for most people. Aside from that..if you have a life insurance policy you might want to consider taking an accelerated death benefit to help you in making your COBRA payments. Just writing this makes me realize how many countless hours of my life over the past few years was spent on this issue just struggling to stay afloat financially including a year long dispute with the ct state dept of social services that just got resolved a couple months ago after sending a certified letter to the commissioner and then several politicians. I am so resentful that I had to go through all that but we do what we have to. I am finally at the point that I can just focus on my rapidly deteriorating health. Anyway..I hate that you or any of us have to deal with this nonsense on top of the health woes but hope that maybe something of my experience might be of help.

Unfortunately many of my friends and relatives are easily led by their silly "no expiration date" commercials. I did actually go for a few days a couple years ago to the one in Pennsylvania at the urging of family and friends. They would have paid to fly me there..limo service to the facility etc. All very curious. A good friend drove me instead and they reimbursed her for expenses. Other than a minimal fee for the hotel I ended up with no out of pocket expenses. The food was great and included! I would say their main difference was the holistic approach. Everyone is assigned a nutritionist, a naturopath, religious or other counselors, massage therapist etc. I wondered how these peripherals were paid for since the insurance companies won't pay for that...unless they padded the other costs to cover it. The facility reminded me more of a hotel than a hospital and I saw more employees than I did actual sick people...which I found odd. Each member of your "team" met with each other and then with you so everyone was all on the same page and no miscommunications. It seems they did have some good concepts but ultimately their treatment plan didn't vary from what my onc had already recommended at Yale and I frankly was glad because I didn't want to leave her. I have never been dissatisfied with her. It also puzzles me why CTCA chooses to focus solely on advanced stage cancer. Niche marketing maybe?

Posts.Content: JillThut wrote: That's what it feels like lately.  Couldn't initially put my finger on it.  Been through so many ups and downs over the past several months, side effects wise.  So having moved on to a very tolerable chemo that makes me feel closer to normal than I have in a very long time, why can't I just embrace the newfound wellness and jump back into living? Because I know if there any options left after this one fails, they are few.  That's why.  I'm feeling like its time to pull up the stakes and move on.  The gig's up.  The party's over. I've skated through the past few years just living life.  Not feeling any particular anxiety even knowing death was inevitable, because I also knew it was not imminent. But now is different.  I feel more pressure than I ever have to use this healthy time wisely, lest I get caught off guard.  I am paralyzed by indecision of how I should be using this time.  I completed my will and designated my life insurance beneficiaries a couple years ago.  I agonized much over those hard choices that had to be made too but am at peace with them. I pulled the "important papers" folder from my file cabinet and assured myself the important stuff was done.  Looked through the pictures I've chosen for the funeral display and was satisfied with the photo choices I've made too.  Found a sticky note and wrote down the names of a few favorite songs and added it to the folder.  Not sure if someone would sing them, play them as background music or what, but I'll let someone else figure that out. I semi joked more than once with my friends, mostly my journaling group, that they will be doing my eulogy.  I'm not religious so if a few people who know me spoke and said what I meant to them that would be good enough.  So that's covered.  So there, I guess I am packed and knowing that does lift the anxiety somewhat. I needed to write this all out because it helps me to put my thoughts into words if I can find them. I hesitate to share this with all of you because I know you all relate.  Many of you are still suffering horrible side effects and some even much closer to the end than I.  Many of you are struggling with the fear of leaving young families.  I am no worse off than any of you ultimately. So im not looking for sympathy nor a list of chemo options.   I already know what's out there and what I've already tried.   I'm a practical person so I will ask for some practical advice.  Where does one have a funeral service if you're not religious?  Do you ask a nearby church if you can use their facility?  Use a room in a funeral home?  Rent a hall?   If I can put that decision to rest I will feel more settled and can hopefully get back to enjoying the rest of life.  Any thoughts? bone, liver and brain mets Jill Dx 10/6/2009, Stage IV, mets Dx IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

In 2007 I was stage 2b with nothing in the lymph nodes nor margins.  My onc recommended chemo and I declined feeling I was probably fine.  Two years later I had wide spread metastasis to liver and bones.  The onc thinks that it must've been there all along ..based on how wide spread it was.  A scan might have detected it..or at the very least a tumor marker test.  He never ordered any scans and let 18 months go by without looking at tumor markers. If it were me..I would try an Al insisting on tumor marker tests and/or periodic scans.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 12:11AM JillThut wrote: I guess the almost empty nest syndrome is bad enough without having stage IV cancer besides. I can fully understand the loneliness of the single parent thing, and dealing with this illness and having it all on you and nowhere to turn for financial and emotional support. I have the opposite problem...a very full nest with three adult children who continue to need me more than they should at this point. Although I admit it's nice having them close sometimes. Yes meetup groups are a good idea for a social outlet. I think with or without illness in my experience the dating world isn't all it's cracked up to be. If you join some adult group things without worrying about finding a partner then maybe it will just happen and if not you can make some new friendships, male and female. It's a transition...and transitions are always hard. Wishing you better days ahead.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2014 09:15PM JillThut wrote: Thanks, all. Grandchildren ARE the greatest blessings in life!  And mine will be staying with me tonight.  Got steroids as a pre- med today and feeling pretty good so I'll be able to enjoy him. Jill, last year my grandson's mother gave me a scrapbook, wanting me to put together some Grandma/Kyle memories.  While I thought it wasn't a bad idea ...at the time I wasn't up for someone else's agenda of what I should be doing with my time.  Because back then every bit of well time was devoted to getting my book together.  But this year I started with the scrap book and I have lots of pictures of the two of us together...pictures of us in the photo booth outside the movie theatre..pictures at Peachwave (frozen yogurt place)...the park...and then near each picture I wrote what the occasion was and maybe something cute Kyle said...like while at Despicable Me 2, Grandma would laugh, then Kyle would laugh and then turn to Grandma and say,   "Why was that funny?" :) Maybe you could put a scrapbook together of the three of you and involve the two year old in it when you can.  She may be more apt to remember things if she helped create it. And hopefully you'll have lots of time to create memories!

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 06:19PM JillThut wrote: Hard to answer. It's really a personal decision. Like any decision at stage 4 it would help to know how long you have...two years? Six? More? None of us really knows. I worked as long as I could until deciding to treat at a new facility that required a greater travelling distance and a once a week all day comittment so I could no longer put in full time hours. I liked my job and didn't want to leave it but it came down to the job or my health so I opted for the better doctor. Financially it continues to be a major struggle but even if finances we're not an issue I wouldn't make a rash decision at the onset of hearing stage 4. Not to minimize the diagnosis but bones mets in particular seem to be the one people are living longest with. Tough that your family is out of state. Make sure it's really what you want to do and know that you can make the decision at any point in the future. Don't rush it. My original onc also was telling me I could leave work on disability but the last thing I wanted to do after hearing his grim prognosis was to give up on my regularly scheduled life...which included my job! Good luck with your decision. Its a tough one....and sorry for your mets diagnosis.

Hiding under the bed, can't deal with it, or simply don't care...I give them no excuses...it's simply bad unacceptable behavior. I have a few close family members that fall into that category too....but then am touched sometimes by offers that I don't expect...like a call from a cousin today who I only see once a year at his annual fourth of July picnic. He called to say he was wondering if I might like to go on a motorcycle ride with him. Totally unexpected. I was in the middle of a family crisis at home with one of my kids...so it just made me cry...but if he calls and offers again...I'll take him up on it! Try not to let the negativity let you down......they are who they are....enjoy being around those who want to be there for you. Even though I know it hurts when you feel rejected by family.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2013 12:34PM JillThut wrote: I saw your friend's fb comment, Katherine and was wondering what you thought of it. I analyzed it for a moment myself and decided I didn't really find it offensive. She is right in one regard as far as things coming a long way. Despite the fact that there still is no cure, I think if we were living with mbc years ago we would have died a lot quicker. I think that's why the general public doesn't get it and doesn't understand why if we're dying...why do we still looked good and often function normally. It dawned on me when a fb friend who knew I was dying 3.5 years sees I'm still here and asked if the prognosis is different now. Years ago when you had metastatic disease and you were dying you did it rather quickly. The fact that we can now prolong life in some cases for years is due to medical advancements. So I understand now the general public's confusion.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 07:04PM JillThut wrote: My two cents on SS disability...I am on it....and now that my full-time cancer job has slowed down somewhat...and im not just talking medical visits...i was spending the better part of each day on the phone fighting ins companies...applying for funds to assist with my exorbitant COBRA payment...fighting with the state for ins...applying for accelerated death benefit...waiver of life insurance premium....refinancing my house....etc etc...basically spending my days doing whatever i could to keep my head above water financially....im sure many of you can relate. Anyway my point was not to complain about all that but rather to acknowledge that what most of us want to keep going is a normal life...for me that includes working and being productive. Been getting depressed lately and i can attribute it directly to not having a set routine. It's important. Being on disability does not mean you cant work. I picked up a couple substitute teaching jobs...will be teaching spanish for 8 weeks. The bigger trick is finding an employer who will use you on a part time very flexible schedule. And for you, Ann I hope it's your current employer. I am very disappointed for you for your current situation.

I've always been of a mind of I don't want to know. I have had CAT, BONE, and MUGA scans every three months for the past 2.5 years and now with the new brain mets I will have MRIs every six weeks. I have people asking me about the results of the MRI...i think they think I will get an answer as to whether the Gammaknife got it all...but i don't think it's that simple...I don't think it disappears that fast and I know what they will really be looking for is further growth. I'd like to put off that information as long as possible. I too just go by how i feel on any given day which is usually good. And I think part of me expects that the scans will be good....the eternal optimist part I guess. As someone on here said...if it weren't for the fact I have to keep up with treatment and scans...I wouldn't know i have mets. Part of me knows that wont last forever...but i cant afford to waste today worrying about tomorrow.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 11:32AM JillThut wrote: Fitz, I read your post before looking at who the poster was and when I did my heart sank. Sorry you've been feeling that the end is near. This is one of those times that misery does NOT want company, certainly not the company of a young mother. So I hope you're wrong. I hope we're both wrong..how's that! Located a funeral home walking distance from me but they were closed. Spoke to them on the phone and made a tentative appt to stop there this week to talk to them. I think I'd want a traditional calling hour thing...and would prefer the actual service to be elsewhere but don't think it's practical since I'd also want a burial after the service and a restaurant or home thing after that. Took a drive around town and this funeral home, two cemetery choices, and a restaurant/ catering facility are all within a mile of my house, walking distance even. So maybe if the funeral home has a room that's not so funeral looking we could do a service there and then burial and then move either to my house or the restaurant facility. Thought about using a room at the catering facility but don't want people sitting around at restaurant tables trying to listen to speakers talk about their memories of me. I want their full attention! My cemetery preference is right in my back yard..there's a brook at the edge of the yard and the cemetery is beyond that. Who else could be buried in their back yard legally?? I've contacted them four times in the past couple years...last time being yesterday. Seems they're always giving me the run around for some reason. It's an old cemetery and she told me yesterday they're still looking at maps to determine what's still available. But she'll have someone get back to me.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 08:53PM JillThut wrote: Wow...I can so relate! You sound just like me! And you're probably beating yourself up for letting the reality make you feel sad...you've got an attitude about it all that pretty much says ignore it..don't let it get to you and just keep on living. You've come to expect it from yourself and probably think others expect it fom you too and you don't want to disappoint. That's the way I feel. And it's funny I also keep fearing getting to the anger stage...thinking it will be all downhill from there...and I get there every time I have progression and a treatment change...and I've had two in the last couple months...I'm currently on my last hair-sparing option but am already making plans to get better at makeup and wigs for whenever...determined to look and feel as normal as possible! I agree with BHD1, once you get on your new treatment you will probably settle in and get your 'you' back! I did...at least back into denial again....for now. Allow yourself all the grieving and venting you need! Don't beat yourself up over it. You're still human...and still you. No hugs...just sending good vibes through mental telepathy;)
Posts.Title: How is this happening?!?.... Lynn1 cmhartley

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 03:04PM - edited Jun 29, 2012 03:05PM by JillThut Expect the worst...but hope for the best and you'll never be disappointed....that's my motto...because the reality is almost always something in between those two extremes. Maybe there is something about going back to an infusion chemo vs oral xeloda? Funny when I failed on taxol and went to xeloda I was very upset. Even upset about missing my weekly infusion routine! But after the initial side effects and a schedule change and dose reduction xeloda became my best friend...mostly for the hair growth I must admit. And I , like you got just a year on it before I had further liver progression...and I was quite upset then too. Same path too....switched to navelbine..required a port that I didn't want. As others have said..generally speaking navelbine is well tolerated....side effect wise..I didn't have big problems with it...it just didn't work. Now adjusting to Gemzar ...and not doing a good job of it but I think I will get there! Looking back now I say ....hey...I got a whole year on xeloda..not bad! This is sounding like a a pep talk and I don't want it to. Fact is your young and should be enjoying sky diving and all the other things life has to offer and not dealing with this BS and the fact that you are makes me angry actually. And you sound like a very lovely and lovable positive person and without even knowing your DH or your loved ones I am sure they are willing to help you through it all...no matter what comes your way. So here's hoping navelbine is the magic bullet for a long long time...but if you hit some bad times...lean on the people around you...it's ok and they probably want you to. .

Posts.Content: JillThut wrote: Long term disability company likes to harass me every six months even though SSDI won't bother for five to seven years. This woman calls me and often keeps me on the phone for as much as forty minutes and the informs me she will be sending lengthy paperwork I need to complete and she wants every weekly pay stub to make sure I didn't earn too much money and "Are there any changes?". Like what? Like my latest scans showed new progression, I just failed on my fourth chemo so it looks like I'll be dying even sooner? While I had her on the line I asked if she had the clerical people there revise the form where they incorrectly report the "minimum benefit". Something she promised to do last time...but no..she didn't and doesn't think she can. But they can send me a verification of benefits letter. And by the way..after January if I'm able to work they will take fifty percent of the earnings away from my benefit. I DON'T CARE! We are talking about 100 dollars a month! She hit a nerve too because I had committed to teaching an adult enrichment Spanish class again for 8 weeks every Tuesday...ended up sick with fevers three Tuesdays prior to the start date of the class so had to back out because I really can't commit to it. I offered to teach just the first class since the new person couldn't do it that night. It was my herceptin only week so I felt ok...really enjoyed it...and so did the class..I could tell...but I walked out of there sad at the end of the night. It felt so good and normal but I knew I couldn't do it every week. I was just about to make myself a cup of coffee this morning...having gotten up very early to bring my son to the methadone clinic, then my grandson to daycare, have to bring my daughter to work at 11. So I told her to just send me the verification letter. She said I'd first have to send her a request in writing.. BS! "Not doing that......and I'm not wasting any more of my time on this call, goodbye.". Hung up feeling like such a B-----! Maybe deep inside progression makes me a little crabbier than I realize! :) bone, liver and brain mets Jill Dx 10/6/2009, Stage IV, mets Dx IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

And just to get the important stuff out of the way..Ebru has been kickin' my butt majorly in Words With Friends! I know the rest of you that have been playing her know what I'm talking about! Living in CT and not knowing what the weather will be like I will shy away from anything outdoors. However my daughter remembers my telling her years ago that I wanted a memorial bench on a nearby biking trail so if that comes to pass, that would satisfy the desire to be remembered at a place that reflects me. Maybe I should check to see If that's even a possibility because I don't want her stressing over it if she can't do it. It's really not that important to me. Thanks for introducing me to the word "celebrant" Diane. Ashamed to say I didn't know what it meant but gathered the meaning from the context and looked it up. :) I will start scouting out possibilities...maybe even today. Found a local funeral home that may be bigger and have more parking than the one I was familiar with. (perhaps I overestimate my popularity) :) Just spent an hour and 45 minutes (most of it on hold) on the phone with the local state dept of social services who wants to cut off my medical benefits at the end of the month. Long story short..I need to find some employment so I can get back into the Medicaid program I was on for the working disabled that has much more liberal asset and income limits. So I'll be out and about over the next few days both funeral shopping and job hunting. At least I now have a purpose and know how I have to spend this "well" time. I don't imagine there is anybody in my usual circle of friends that can relate to that. But I suspect some of you out there can!

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 11:49AM - edited Sep 10, 2013 01:12PM by JillThut Curveball, one of my fellow journalists just passed in May and he had a celebration of life service about a month later and it was very nice. But he was cremated so his family didn't do the traditional calling hour thing or burial which I think I want. Also I'm not sure if I had a memorial thing down the road if people would show up other than family. And I'd rather have it all done at once for my kids so perhaps they can move on quicker. I think that would be their preference too. They're young adults, 32, 30, and 23. I plan to go back to the Adult Ed office to see if I could sub for their English as a Second language classes again. That's what I did when I first became eligible for Medicaid for the working disabled. Although it's not always the easiest thing to do for 3/4 hours at a clip. Sometimes I get painful muscle spasms ...they don't last long..at home I either yell or breathe through it and it usually passes quickly. Have to be on your game all the time teaching a class. They might not even need me. I think I can find something though, and hopefully soon!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 03:03PM JillThut wrote: Went to the Adullt Ed office to talk about subbing for them again. Got a warm reception..of course you get the "oh you look good are you doing better?" questions. But they seemed genuinely happy to see me and also happy to have me back subbing for them. Had to fill out another brief application because it's a new school year. Also need to wait for board of ed meeting so they can vote on it. I know it sounds odd..but getting that out of the way I came home and practically skipped across the living room I felt so good. Almost wanted to post my day on the"what are you doing for fun" thread! Now that I have a plan....going to get back to living!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2013 06:47PM JillThut wrote: I am also claustrophobic and have frequent brain MRIs. There is a cage that sort of clamps down over your head but not touching it. It might help to know that if need be you can easily slide out of it on your own. I've been calmer about it once I realized this. I always take 1 mil of Lorazepam about 20 minutes before. I try to go in there like I want to be there and am taking my nap. I have to divorce myself mentally from it and go someplace else in my head. There are lots of noises though so I try to incorporate them into my fantasies as being something else. The techs sometimes like to talk to you and tell you which pose they're taking. I ask them not to. It's not like I can switch positions for the shot since you have to lie perfectly still so if they talk it brings me back to the reality of where I am. I hope I'm not making this sound worse than it is. I've done several and you get though it. Those are just my strategies. It's never longer than 45 minutes tops. I would say take whatever you can to mke you groggy. That should help. Good luck with it!

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 04:44PM JillThut wrote: My company maintained me on their health insurance policy while I was on short term disability...twice.  I was out for some months..returned to work for about four months then went out on std again.  Then when I left work for good I got ltd and SSDI.  At that point I had to pay cobra for my health coverage which was 645 a month for just me.  That was difficult but for part of it I applied to the health well foundation for assistance, which I got.  1800 for one year. I also applied to the Dept of Social services for Medicaid insurance for the "working disabled". I took some teaching sub jobs in order to qualify for that.  The income and asset limits are much higher for the working disabled program also known as med-connect. And there is no minimum number of hours you need to work.  I also was eligible for a few years off and on of unemployment compensation since the new laws ...CT anyway....don't require you seek full time work if disabled.  So that helped greatly toward being able to pay the COBRA.  Rather than have the state give me Medicaid insurance they agreed to a premium purchase arrangement whereby they picked up my COBRA premium.  This way I had a private medical plan vs state which might have afforded me more treatment options if needed since some facilities or procedures don't accept Medicaid.  After being eligible for Medicare I was also at that point low enough income even without the working disabled program to be eligible for  Medicaid as a secondary insurance.  I'm comfortable now but those two years prior to being Medicare eligible were a struggle and a constant researching of funds, filling out forms etc to make it work. All this is more relevant if you are self supporting.  If you have a spouse with good medial benefits I imagine you could go on his policy despite when regular enrollment is due to this being what they'd call a "qualifying event".

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 12:27PM JillThut wrote: I remember when I first realized that life's drama doesn't stop just because you're dying of cancer....what a rude awakening! In fact I wasn't my stoic self back when when I had my first chemo dose..i pictured vomiting the minute they put in the IV which of course wasn't the case....and i was scared...so I cried. And then my son's gf called to say the local police had arrested my son on a motor vehicle charge. From the infusion room I called the police to find it was in fact "possession of heroine with intent to sell"....and I cried again. I really feel for your situation, Luann, and can definitely relate. And i also have a 21 yr old daughter who is not always the nicest person. With any luck..eventually they will grow up to be responsible caring individuals...we just won't be around to see it. I have a couple siblings who have been noticeably absent (and two who are attentive). I had to shame my brother into helping get some desperately needed dressers for me with his truck since now all three "adult" children are living with me. So many people have said to me when first diagnosed "if there's anything I can do". I have to wonder how they would react if i gave them each a list That being said...when im gone I really don't want anybody feeling guilty about what they did and didn't do...certainly not my kids..not even my siblings....but right now they can wallow in it.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2014 10:18PM JillThut wrote: 27 pounds due to nausea is a lot!  My heart goes out to you.  My onc referred me to a palliative care team in the same facility about a year ago, reason being I requested Ritalin for extreme fatigue.  Her APRN had never even heard of using it for cancer patients so I think I might have been referred more because they have more familiarity with things that help minimize side effects.  As it happened I got the Ritalin but never got to use it because I ended up in the hospital for a week and then I switched chemos so no longer needed it.  I also wanted to try marinol for nausea once since nothing else worked and the onc wouldn't prescribe it (although oddly enough her APRN would at one point but it was temporarily unavailable at the pharmacies.). Never got that either because of a chemo switch again. I wouldn't hesitate to use them again if need be.  I am hoping that they have another solution to nausea other than the usual zofran, compazine, emends etc.  None of those things ever did anything for my nausea if it was severe.  Staying on steroids for a while did lessen the nausea somewhat for me.  But I would guess you've already been on them.  I sure hope they can find a solution.  I gathered from a comment you made on another thread kind of marveling at people who can still get out and enjoy life, that you weren't doing too well.

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2012 10:52AM - edited Sep 19, 2012 06:26PM by JillThut It might be just me but I find that if I take oral zofran vs IV it doesn't constipate me...where anything anti-nausea IV ...zofran, iloxi means instant clog. Last time the nurse tried to give it to me intervenously I stopped her and asked for oral instead. As far as staying on top of constipation ...of course different things work for different people...but I take three stool softeners and three sennas (both generic) and that usually works. I never take compazine because I've had bad reactions to it in the past....super jitteriness.
